metadata.title: Foktoi | ফোকতোই | Rural Recipes
metadata.description:
Foktoi by Anindita Roy | রুরাল রেসিপির পঁচিশ তম পর্ব, জলপাইগুড়ির - ময়নাগুড়ির বাসিন্দা -অনিন্দিতা রায়ের হাতের রান্না :  ফোকতোই

True to its name, this recipe embodies uniqueness and intrigue in many aspects. It stands as one of the most cherished traditional recipes of the Rajbongshi community, descendants of the Cooch dynasty, in North Bengal. This exotic dish combines dry fish, flattened rice, taro leaves, and, notably, homemade soda (known as Chyaka), along with a few essential spices like green chili and salt. The preparation process is simple and easily accessible.  In this episode, we not only delve into the traditional recipe but also witness age-old cooking methods, including the use of wooden grinders, locally crafted portable stoves, and jute stems as firewood to ignite the stove.  Foktoi holds a significant place in the cultural heritage of the Rajbongshi community, serving as a signature dish for them.

Rural local recipes are integral part of Intangible Cultural Heritage and needs to be preserved and promoted. We at banglanatak dot com have been working for the past 22+ years to safeguard and promote local cultural heritages in rural spaces across India. We are now launching a new initiative of documenting rural recipes and bringing them closer to the food lovers of the world. We request all to subscribe to our new channel Rural Recipes and stay tuned there to know, learn and try out local delicacies.

transcription_bengali: [00:00:23] এই মুহূর্তে আমরা ডুয়ার্সে, জলপাইগুড়ি জেলায়।
[00:00:32] আমরা সেখানে যাব এবং আপনাদের দেখাব
[00:00:35] এই এলাকার বিখ্যাত, ইউনিক এবং ট্র্যাডিশনাল একটা রেসিপি।
[00:00:50] আমি ভালো আছি। অনেকদিন পরে দেখা হলো।
[00:01:04] তাহলে দর্শকদের জন্য আপনি কী বানাচ্ছেন?
[00:01:11] আজ আমি এই এলাকার খুব বিখ্যাত একটা খাবার বানাব।
[00:01:24] (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে ভুল অনুবাদ আছে: ‘spiny lobster’ বলা হলেও আসলে শুকনো মাছ/শুঁটকি বোঝানো) ছোট ছোট করে ভেঙে নেওয়া শুকনো মাছ দিয়ে,
[00:01:31] এর মূল উপকরণ—যেটা ফোকতোইয়ের নামেও খুব পরিচিত,
[00:01:34] আমি দেখাব কীভাবে এটা বানাতে হয়।
[00:01:41] আমি মাছ দিয়ে এক প্লেট ভাত খেয়ে ফেলতে পারি—এটা আমার একটা শখ।
[00:03:17] (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে অস্পষ্ট/ভুল: ‘ভোলা মাছের শুঁটকি’ ইত্যাদি বলা—প্রসঙ্গত শুঁটকি প্রস্তুতি/ভাঙার কথা)
[00:03:21] প্রথমে (অস্পষ্ট: ‘তেঁতুল’ বলা—সম্ভবত ভুল; আসলে শুঁটকি/উপকরণ ভাঙা) কুচিয়ে/ভেঙে নেব।
[00:04:00] আচ্ছা, আপনাকে কম ঝাল করে দেব,
[00:04:41] আমরা রান্নায় তেল ব্যবহার করি না।
[00:06:34] আমার মনে হয় প্রায় হয়ে গেছে।
[00:06:45] (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে বলা) হাই ব্লাড প্রেসার/লো ব্লাড প্রেসারে ভালো।
[00:08:25] না, আলুর বড়ার সঙ্গে খেলে ভালো হবে।
[00:08:30] আচ্ছা, তাহলে আলুর বড়া হওয়া পর্যন্ত অপেক্ষা।
[00:08:33] আলুর বড়া হতে হতে আমি আপনাদের একটা গান শোনাব।
[00:09:13] তো আলুর বড়া আর (ফিশ/সাইড) বড়া রেডি।
[00:09:34] কিন্তু লঙ্কা আর রসুনের গন্ধ পাচ্ছি।
[00:10:34] আজকের এপিসোড কেমন লাগল, কমেন্টে জানান।
[00:10:39] আবার দেখা হবে নতুন রেসিপি নিয়ে, নতুন জায়গায়।
transcription_english: [00:00:16] Welcome to West Bengal’s tea country.
[00:00:23] Right now we are in the Dooars, Jalpaiguri district.
[00:00:27] A small town in Jalpaiguri district—Moinaguri.
[00:00:32] We will go there and show you
[00:00:35] a famous, unique, and traditional recipe from this locality.
[00:00:46] Anindita, how are you?
[00:00:48] I’m fine—how are you?
[00:00:50] I’m fine. It’s been a long time since we met.
[00:00:53] Come inside.
[00:00:54] Okay, let’s go.
[00:00:59] We have come to your home with a new episode of Rural Recipe.
[00:01:04] So, what are you making for our viewers?
[00:01:11] Today I’m going to make a very famous local dish.
[00:01:15] It is called Foktoi.
[00:01:22] It’s an interesting name—what is it made of?
[00:01:24] (Transcript is mistranslated as “spiny lobster”; context indicates it’s made from dried fish/shutki, broken into small pieces.)
[00:01:31] A key component—without which it’s not really called foktoi—is “chheka” (homemade alkaline soda/khar).
[00:01:34] I will show you how to make it.
[00:01:41] I can finish a whole plate of rice with fish—this is one of my hobbies.
[00:01:45] Wow, that’s great.
[00:01:47] So, let’s start.
[00:01:48] In North Bengal there are many kinds of taro (kachu).
[00:01:54] There are different varieties—boi kachu, shola kachu, maan kachu—
[00:02:01] and the most popular is kalo kachu.
[00:02:05] Since we are making foktoi today, we need kalo kachu leaves. Right?
[00:02:10] Please tell our viewers what we need.
[00:02:15] We need kachu leaves, ginger, garlic, green chili, and khar/chheka.
[00:03:39] Now we add three items: chili, ginger, and garlic.
[00:03:51] It will be spicy; the host prefers less spicy so they adjust it.
[00:04:17] There is no water, so it’s not sticky.
[00:04:33] The pan is heated; now we add shurki (dry fish) and mix.
[00:04:41] We do not use oil in this cooking (healthier; older style used oil).
[00:04:55] If we mix it, the fish becomes soft.
[00:05:02] It’s an exotic combination: chira, kachu leaves, and dry fish.
[00:05:08] Optionally, we can add takua (river snails).
[00:05:17] It’s almost done; now we take it out and grind/mash it.
[00:05:34] Add chheka/khar (transcript says “kata”), then add water, then add kachu leaves.
[00:06:00] The water is hot; add kachu leaves, boil briefly (not too long).
[00:06:19] While it boils, mash the shurki mixture.
[00:06:37] Boil a bit more, then add chira.
[00:07:20] Add salt and mix.
[00:07:57] Now it is ready; cover it.
[00:08:19] How should we eat it—
[00:08:25] better with potato fritters (aloor bora) than with rice.
[00:08:33] While fritters are getting ready, she sings a song (sarinda mentioned).
[00:09:13] Now fritters are ready; the host tastes it.
[00:09:34] Smells of chili and garlic; tastes good; different flavor; salt is balanced.
[00:10:18] Very nice with potato fritters.
[00:10:21] Episode ends: subscribe, watch new videos, and comment how you liked it. Thank you.
